title-group.article-title: 4in1 Procedure in Treating Congenital Dislocation of Patella in Children

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Congenital dislocation of patella (CDP) is a rare condition and surgery is needed to treat CDP once a diagnosis is made. The 4in1 procedure includes lateral release, correction of quadriceps, Roux‐Goldthwait procedure, and medial patello‐femoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction. This study was aimed at evaluating the efficacy and outcome of the 4in1 procedure in the operative treatment of CDP.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: CDP patients were retrospectively collected from two operative centers from January 2013 to December 2024. For all patients, patellae on both sides were examined by x‐ray, CT, and MR bilaterally. Ten patients (14 patellae) underwent 4in1 procedure. Gradual passive and active exercises of knee motion and quadriceps were begun as tolerated. Kujala Score was collected before and after the operation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This cohort included 10 patients (4 males, 6 females), with 4 cases of bilateral involvement and 6 unilateral cases (total 14 limbs). The mean age at surgery was 8.36 years (4–14 years), with an average surgical duration of 157.7 min and intraoperative blood loss of 35.6 mL. Kujala scores improved from 39.9 preoperatively to 82.9 postoperatively (p < 0.001). All patients were followed up for at least 1 year. All patellae were centerized on the groove postoperatively with no recurrence.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: CDP is a rare lower limb skeletal disorder requiring thorough evaluation. Early diagnosis and 4in1 procedure optimize patellar stability and knee function, preventing long‐term complications.

abstract.p: Congenital dislocation of patella (CDP) is a rare condition. The 4in1 procedure includes lateral release, correction of quadriceps, Roux‐Goldthwait procedure, and medial patello‐femoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction. Early diagnosis and the 4in1 procedure optimize patellar stability and knee function, preventing long‐term complications.

p.mixed-citation: M.‐j.Chen, Y.‐C.Wang, Q.‐C.Ma, et al., “4in1 Procedure in Treating Congenital Dislocation of Patella in Children,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2647–2652, 10.1111/os.70144.PMC1240485940744519

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by Shanghai Health Care Commission Clinical Research Special Project for Health Industry, 202240106; Xinhua Hospital Institutional Clinical Research Innovation Project, 23XHCR13C.
Meng‐Jie Chen and Yi‐Chen Wang contributed equally to this study and are joint first authors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Congenital dislocation of patella (CDP) is a rare condition characterized as persistent irreducible lateral dislocation of the patella [1]. Although the exact causes are unknown, CDP is usually accompanied by dysfunction of the quadriceps. Often, CDP is bilateral and familial. Many genetic disorders are presented by CDP, such as small patella syndrome (SPS), Down syndrome, and congenital arthrogryposis [2].

Surgery should be done once the diagnosis is confirmed to reduce the incidence of further deformity progression of the knee. Several operative techniques are available to treat CDP. Extensive lateral release and medial plication were indispensable procedures to obtain patella‐femoral congruency in the past. Nevertheless, this 2in1 procedure is not always sufficient to maintain the reduction of patella, especially in older patients [3].

We started a 4in1 procedure (Figure 1) to treat CDP since 2020. The procedure includes lateral release, correction of quadriceps, Roux‐Goldthwait procedure (medial transfer of the lateral third or half of the patellar tendon) and medial patello‐femoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction. This study was aimed to (i) introduce the basic process of the 4in1 procedure; (ii) evaluate the efficacy and outcome of the 4in1 procedure in the operative treatment of CDP.

caption.p: 4in1 procedure. Red indicates V‐Y lengthening of quadriceps. Blue indicates MPFL reconstruction. Yellow indicates Roux‐Goldthwait procedure. Lateral release was not shown here.

sec.title: General Information
sec.p: CDP patients were retrospectively collected from two operative centers from January 2013 to December 2024. The Institutional Ethics Committee approved this study (No. XHEC‐D‐2025‐037). Informed consent was acquired for all related patients.

The inclusion criteria were as follows: (i) patients diagnosed with CDP (history and radiological image); (ii) aged 4–14 years; (iii) 4in1 procedure applied to the patients; (iv) for patients of bilateral involvement, surgeries for both sides were applied separately with an interval of at least 3 months.

The exclusion criteria were as follows: (i) dislocation of patella not due to congenital causes (such as traumatic dislocation); (ii) accompanying condition around knee (genu valgus); (iii) other surgery (not 4in1 procedure) applied or previous surgery history of the lower limbs; (iv) incomplete history.

sec.title: Radiological Imaging
sec.p: For all patients, patellae on both sides were examined by X‐ray (anterior–posterior view, axis view and lateral view), CT, and MR bilaterally. CT was applied the next day to the operation to confirm reduction of patella. X‐ray was used for further follow‐ups.

sec.title: Preparation
sec.p: Examine the knee with the patient under anesthesia. With the patient supine, a tourniquet was placed on the upper thigh.

sec.title: Arthroscopy
sec.p: After sterilization and draping, use standard inferolateral and inferomedial portals to perform a diagnostic arthroscopy. This evaluation is necessary for decision making of the treatment. Any intraarticular damage can be treated at this moment once diagnosed.

sec.title: Lateral Release
sec.p: Make a 4‐cm incision, starting from the level of the proximal pole of the patella, 2 cm lateral and parallel to the lateral border of the patella and extend the incision distally. Carry dissection down through the subcutaneous tissues. Release the vastus lateralis and any tight iliotibial band. Advance to the lateral border of the patella. Carefully incise the lateral retinaculum. Take care not to injure the synovium.

sec.title: Correction of Quadriceps
sec.p: Extended the incision superomedially to the level of the middle third of the femur and inferolaterally to the tibial tuberosity. Expose the anterior thigh muscles and lengthen the quadriceps in a V‐Y fashion or Z‐plasty. In some cases, advancement of vastus medialis was used.

sec.title: MPFL Reconstruction
sec.p: Make a 2‐cm incision proximal to the lateral malleolus and harvest the peroneus longus tendon in standard fashion.
Make a 2‐cm incision from adductor tubercle to the medial epicondyle of the femur to expose the insertion of MPFL.

Dissect subcutaneously and expose the proximal medial retinaculum at its insertion into the proximal portion of the patella. Make a 1.5‐cm incision in the retinaculum adjacent to the quadriceps insertion.

Use blunt dissection with a curved Kelly clamp to spread toward the medial epicondyle between the MPFL and the capsular layer in order to create a soft tissue tunnel. Shuttle both tails of the graft through the MPFL tunnel to the femoral insertion site.

Select the site for the femoral tunnel approximately 8 mm distal to the adductor tubercle. Take care not to touch the distal physes of the femur in cases of open physes. Confirm the correct position with the C‐arm.
At the selected femoral tunnel site, ream a tunnel the diameter of doubled tendon. Fix the tendon with an anchor screw (Double Medical Technology Inc).

With the knee held in 60° of flexion and patella centralized in the groove (assistant can push the patella medially from the lateral border), maintain this graft length while it is secured with another two anchor screws to the insertion of the patella.

sec.title: Roux‐Goldthwait Procedure
sec.p: The lateral portion of the patellar tendon is detached from the tibia and slipped under the medial portion, then attached to the medial fibrous plane with an anchor screw.

sec.title: Completion of Surgery
sec.p: Reintroduce the arthroscope to confirm the patella to be centralized within the trochlear groove. Close the incision in a standard fashion. Apply a long leg orthosis or cast with the knee 30° in flexion.

sec.title: Postoperative Rehabilitation
sec.p: At 3 weeks after surgery, the immobilizer was discontinued and weight bearing was allowed as tolerated. Gradual passive and active exercises of knee motion and quadriceps were begun according to the instructions of the formal physiotherapist. Patients were allowed to participate in sports in 4–6 months depending on the rehabilitation progress.

sec.title: Range of Motion
sec.p: Range of motion (ROM) was measured using a goniometer with 5° measuring accuracy. According to Judet's criteria, final flexion was measured to evaluate clinical outcomes as excellent (>100°), good (80°–99°), fair (50°–79°), or poor (< 50°) [4].

sec.title: Kujala Score
sec.p: The Kujala Score is a self‐administered questionnaire for patients suffering from knee pain consisting of 13 questions that relate to specified activities, pain severity, and clinical symptoms [5]. It is scored out of 100 points, with 100 being the highest possible score.

sec.title: Statistical Methods
sec.p: Statistical analyses were applied by SPSS (25.0, Chicago, IL). Variables were expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD). p < 0.05 was set as the threshold for statistical significance. For CDP with bilateral involvement, data were collected separately for left and right sides. Shapiro–Wilk's method was used for the normality test.

sec.title: Demographic Data
sec.p: Sixteen pediatric patients met the diagnostic criteria for CDP. Six were excluded: four underwent other surgical procedures, one presented with concomitant fracture, and one had significant genu valgum. The final cohort included 10 patients and 14 limbs (4 males, 6 females), with 4 cases of bilateral involvement and 6 unilateral cases (4 left, 2 right). Comorbidities included: one small patella syndrome, one Down syndrome, one cerebral palsy, one left renal agenesis, and one clubfoot. The mean age at surgery was 8.36 years (4–14 years), with an average surgical duration of 157.7 min and intraoperative blood loss of 35.6 mL. Kujala scores improved from 39.9 preoperatively to 82.9 postoperatively (p < 0.001). Shapiro–Wilk's normality test was accepted for all the parameters. In the following paragraphs, we present two representative cases from this study.

sec.title: Clinical Outcomes
sec.p: All patients were followed up for at least 1 year. All patellae were centerized on the groove postoperatively with no recurrence. All knees showed full passive extension and 120° flexion (the mean postoperative flexion was 142.7°, Table 1). All met the excellent Judet criteria, although at the last evaluation, active knee extension was achieved with a residual quadriceps strength deficit in a few cases. In case 1, severe quadriceps strength deficit was bilaterally presented preoperatively. It took one entire year of strength training of the quadriceps for case 1 to gain the ability to squat and sit up without assistance.

caption.p: Description of characteristics of patients including gender, age at operation, accompanying conditions, duration of operation, bleeding in the operation, Kujala scores, and ROM before and after the operation.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: The patient was a 12‐year‐old male admitted for progressive difficulty in squatting with both knees for over 1 year without obvious triggers or trauma history. The main symptoms included inability for full squatting and uncoordinated gait. The patient had a 16‐year‐old brother with no related conditions and no family history of similar diseases. His developmental history was normal. At age 2, he underwent atrial septal defect closure in Shanghai Children's Hospital. Physical examination showed equal leg length with no genu varum or valgum. Active squatting was limited to 30° knee flexion bilaterally. Passive knee ranges of motion were −5° to 90° bilaterally. Patellae were laterally displaced during flexion with skin pigmentation. Patellae were partially reducible medially in extension. First and second toes were more slender as compared to fourth and fifth toes with widened interdigital spaces. Nail development was normal. Laboratory exams were normal. Knee X‐rays (Figure 2) showed absent patellae on lateral views and extremely small, laterally displaced patellae on axial views. Preoperative CT (Figure 2) showed small, kidney‐shaped patellae with lateral displacement. Patellar long‐axis diameter was 2.2 cm and patella‐tibia tubercle distance was 6.0 cm (ratio 0.37, normal 0.8–1.2). Femoral trochlea was completely flattened (near‐zero depth). Preoperative knee MRI (Figure 2) showed elongated, hypoplastic MPFL with underdeveloped medial femoral condyle. Postoperative CT (Figure 2) showed patellar reduction. Genetic testing confirmed heterozygous TBX4 variant (c.466_469dup), which was inherited paternally. All imaging and genetic findings lead to SPS.

caption.p: Case I: (A) Knee x‐rays in case 1 (lateral/axial views). (B) Preoperative CT (small, kidney‐shaped patellae with lateral displacement). (C) Preoperative knee MRI (dislocation of patellae and MPFL elongation). (D) Postoperative CT (patellar reduction).

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: An 11‐year‐old girl was admitted to the hospital due to weakness in lower limbs for over 4 years with no obvious cause. Symptoms became more pronounced after prolonged fatigue or physical activity. She was prone to falling when walking quickly or climbing stairs. Both her father and grandmother had a history of leg weakness and were prone to falling. There was no history of former surgery or trauma. Physical examination showed no leg length discrepancy or obvious other deformity in the limbs. There was no significant limitation in knee flexion or extension. The patellae dislocated laterally in full extension and reduced in flexion. Imaging (Figure 3) studies were indicative of bilateral dislocated patellae with patellar dysplasia. Postoperative CT (Figure 3) confirmed favorable reduction of patellae bilaterally.

caption.p: Case 2: (A–D) Preoperative x‐ray, CT, and MR showed dysplastic lateral dislocated patellae bilaterally. (E) Postoperative CT confirmed favorable reduction of patellae bilaterally.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: CDP is a very rare condition. We aimed to evaluate the outcomes of 4in1 procedure in treating CDP.

CDP sometimes occurs in otherwise normal children as in case 2, but more often CDP is in accompaniment of severe multiple or syndromic birth defects. In our study, case 1 was diagnosed as SPS, also known by multiple terms such as ischiopatella dysplasia or Scott‐Taor syndrome. SPS is a rare skeletal dysplasia first reported by Scott and Taor in 1979 [6]. Vanek later described it as ischiopatella dysplasia in 1981 [7]. Bonger identified a TBX4 gene mutation in an SPS family in 2004 [8], which was consistent with genetic findings in case 1. Other syndromes easily confused with CDP include Nail‐Patella Syndrome, which is caused by LMX1B mutations, featuring nail dysplasia, iliac horns, and nephropathy [9], and Familial Patellar Aplasia‐Hypoplasia (PTLAH), which is linked to 17q21‐q22, with isolated patellar hypoplasia (no TBX4 mutations) [10].

sec.title: Role of MPFL
sec.p: MPFL plays a major role in maintaining the stability of the patella. Reconstruction of MPFL is the key procedure in the operative treatment of CDP, especially in older patients. Dysfunction of quadriceps is another etiological factor of CDP [11]. Those were the reasons we included MPFL and quadriceps in the 4in1 procedure as a definitive surgical solution to CDP in this study.

MR is the most important radiologic examination for CDP before the surgery. MR can present thickened eccentric non‐ossified patellar cartilage, elongated MPFL, hypoplastic medial femoral condyle, and trochlear dysplasia [12, 13], which contribute to patellar instability and chondral damage in CDP.

Patients of CDP often present with recurrent patellar dislocation during childhood and adolescence. Early diagnosis is crucial to guide timely surgical intervention, allowing patellar repositioning and normal knee development.

sec.title: Advantages of the 4in1 Procedure
sec.p: In the past, over 100 different procedures have been introduced for patellar instability in adults [14, 15]. In this study, 4in1 procedure was applied in CDP treatment. The procedure includes lateral release, correction of quadriceps, MPFL reconstruction and Roux‐Goldthwait patellar tendon transfer. We used to do a 2in1 procedure (lateral release and medial plication) but that turned out to be insufficient to maintain reduction of patella and lead to recurrence especially in older children. The duration of 4in1 procedure was averaged about 2 h. This procedure was relatively not technique demanding and safe to proceed. There was no consensus regarding the age limit of MPFL reconstruction [16, 17]. In our cases, two patients underwent the surgery at the age of 4 successfully. Konkel treated patellofemoral instability with Judet quadriceps release, combined with “à la carte” realignment procedures, which included trochleoplasty, distal procedures on the tibial tuberosity, and femoral shortening and derotational osteotomy [18]. Nevertheless, as patients were skeletal immature in this study, we did not choose to operate on the bone.

sec.title: Surgical Tips
sec.p: We believe adjusting the tension of the MPFL graft is the most difficult part. Too much tension may lead to medial impingement. Immobilization was maintained with the knee in 30° flexion after surgery.

sec.title: Postoperative Rehabilitation
sec.p: In this group of CDP, no recurrence was recorded at least 1 year postoperatively. Training of quadriceps strength was strongly recommended to the patients once immobilization was discontinued. In our cases, knee function recovered favorably after surgery and most patients could go back to sports as tolerated. Staged bilateral surgeries were arranged for CDP of bilateral involvement during school vacations so as to minimize disruption to the patient's education.

sec.title: Limitations and Strengths
sec.p: We have to admit limitations exist in the current study. First, the case number was not big as CDP is a highly rare condition. Second, this was a retrospective two‐center study. Third, genetic exam was not applied to each case and possible concomitant syndromes could have been missed. Fourth, follow up was a 1‐year short term, but we will continue to follow these cases up in the future. Also, the strengths of our study lie in favorable outcomes, especially with no occurrence at current last visits and providing surgeons with an organized procedure to treat CDP.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: CDP is a rare lower limb skeletal disorder requiring thorough evaluation. MRI is critical to assess knee dysplasia and guide surgical planning. Early diagnosis and 4in1 procedure optimize patellar stability and knee function, preventing long‐term complications.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Meng‐Jie Chen: writing – original draft, investigation. Yi‐Chen Wang: software, methodology. Qi‐Chao Ma: investigation, software, methodology, conceptualization. Qin Zhang: investigation, software. Ting‐Ting Li: visualization. Fang‐Chun Jin: funding acquisition, supervision, methodology, conceptualization. Yi Luo: writing – review and editing, supervision, investigation, methodology, conceptualization.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: All listed authors and all patients involved in the study.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available on request from the corresponding author. The data are not publicly available due to privacy or ethical restrictions.
